;中英关系恶化之前，我的印象是英国完全向世界开放，没有太多警惕。但进入2020年以来，风云突变，国家对中国极度谨慎和怀疑。

;

;对华正确态度是什么？由于英国媒体将国内政治置于外交政策之上，未能彻底解释中美之间的地缘政治竞争。许多英国人可能对唐宁街10号态度的巨大转变感到困惑。他们的日常生活严重依赖中国制造，无论他们喜欢与否。

;

;当我生活在中国时，我的心态受到中国官方媒体的影响，所以我相信中国政府正在做的事情是基于主权原则的合理性。在英国生活的19年里，我接触到了更高的人权和自由价值观，这与中国强调主权和社会责任是不一致的。

;

;从西方价值观来看，中国政府给人的印象是落后于西方的趋势。我感觉到我出生、接受教育和工作的中国很像19世纪的英国——一个经济强劲的国家，但社会不公平、不平等，饱受种族主义困扰。

;

;当我听到中国王毅在国际关系论坛上试图说服首尔和东京重启与北京的合作时，表达了这样的观点时，我惊讶地发现，即使是中国最高层的外交也没有取得多大进展：“当我们去美国时，他们分不清中国人、日本人和韩国人。我们在欧洲可能也会经历同样的情况。不管你把头发染得多金，鼻子做得多尖，你永远不会成为西方人。”

;

;如果我今天生活在中国，我会给王热烈的掌声因为大陆的心态是一种对西方帝国主义的愤怒，而西方帝国主义的基础是相信白人的优越性。只有少数英国人意识到前殖民地国家中持续存在的怨恨情绪。与此同时，中国人却没有意识到，许多英国人对帝国主义的黑暗时代感到羞耻，并正在尽最大努力与自己国家的种族主义作斗争。

;

;儒家思想强调对家庭、统治者和公民的责任和义务。 2000多年来，国家对中国社会产生了深远的影响。西方启蒙运动的精神并没有触及中国大陆社会的大部分人。俄罗斯共产主义对中国来说是一个相对较新的事物。它的历史只能追溯到一百多年前。今天的中国政治是俄罗斯共产主义、儒家思想和中国共产党自己探索的混合体，与清朝时期的民主相差并不远。

;

;作为第一代英国移民来自中国的我对中英关系的恶化感到非常沮丧。我最近在我的一篇专栏文章中采访了前英国财政部首席秘书、现任亚洲基础设施投资银行副行长丹尼·亚历山大。

;

;我原本以为会见到一位压力很大的英国人鉴于加拿大最近暂停了与该银行的关系，原因是该银行的全球通讯总监（加拿大人）辞职，称该银行“由共产党控制”。不过，亚历山大一脸轻松地表示，在当前环境下他并没有感受到任何压力，英国和中国一样，对亚投行的工作持积极态度。

;

;当我问他亚投行是否是他回答说，该银行是一个独立组织，只支持亚洲的优秀项目。

;

;这次采访不仅向我强调了一些说法我在英文媒体上看到的消息不实，也说明了西方与中国之间的误解程度。

;

;我们应该避免做出极端的判断。除了黑与白之外，还有很多灰色地带可供维护和平。无论西方对中国政府的人权记录有多大异议，它都需要保持耐心，学习如何与这个新兴大国和平合作，应对气候变化和俄罗斯入侵乌克兰。

;

;

;

;“平壤发出的信息他说：“美国和韩国的行动方式正在促使朝鲜更接近考虑援引其核武器使用准则。”

;

;

;首尔和华盛顿已加强防务合作作为回应，举行联合军事演习拥有先进的隐形飞机和美国战略资产。

;

;华盛顿于四月份首次宣布将部署一艘能够向朝鲜半岛发射携带核弹头的弹道导弹的潜艇，当时尹正正在进行国事访问。

;美国芯片出口限制使一些中国风险投资者不再支持生成人工智能（总部位于硅谷的 BlueRun Ventures (BRV) 中国分公司的一位投资者表示，随着中国公司竞相创建类似于 OpenAI 的 ChatGPT 的服务，人工智能）初创企业。

;

;中国的人工智能发展可能会BRV 中国执行合伙人 Jui Tan 周四在接受《华盛顿邮报》采访时表示，短期内将面临挑战，因为美国对先进图形处理单元 (GPU) 出口的限制“吓跑了一些人”。

;

;“你担心你投资应用场景、投​​资人才后，可能半途就意识到自己没有足够的计算能力，无法获得足够的 GPU，”Tan 说。 “我认为这给企业家和投资者带来了某种恐惧。”

;

;去年 8 月，美国商务部禁止美国公司 Nvidia 和 Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) 销售其一些最先进的产品。芯片运往中国。这一决定导致中国人工智能行业争先恐后地争夺英伟达生产的有限 GPU 供应，英伟达几乎垄断了用于训练人工智能系统的处理器。

;

;当中国科技巨头争论中国在人工智能方面落后了多远时关键技术的缺乏阻碍了一些国内投资者加入生成式人工智能潮流。

;

;中国亿万富翁投资者、电动汽车巨头比亚迪联合创始人夏作全上周告诉《华盛顿邮报》他对ChatGPT级别的产品很快会在中国诞生持怀疑态度。

;

;不过，谭表示BRV致力于投资中国的人工智能领域。他表示，这家风险投资公司计划将去年 5 月筹集的 55 亿元人民币（8.17 亿美元）新基金中的 50% 以上分配给人工智能初创企业。

;

;Tan 表示，他从长远看，“足够的资本和人才”将能够解决中国的算力困境。他表示，在不久的将来，中国的企业家可以擅长创建不需要密集计算能力的独特的生成式人工智能应用程序。

;

;Tan 表示，BRV 中国还重点关注机器人和新能源等领域。 .

;

;该公司是中国电动汽车制造商理想汽车的支持者，该公司于 2021 年 8 月在香港上市。Tan 表示，BRV China 也希望与香港的行业进行更密切的合作。这座城市是人才、数据和金融中心，可以帮助中国的人工智能初创企业走向全球。

;

;BRV China 由 Tan 于 2005 年创立，是众多在中国投资的风险投资公司之一。应对日益复杂的地缘政治环境。中美紧张关系引发了人们对美国对中国技术的投资正在枯竭的担忧。

;

;源代码资本是一家总部位于北京的风险投资公司，从中国地方政府和全球有限合伙人那里筹集资金，该公司正在结束对中国技术的投资。中国媒体周二报道了种子融资计划。

;

;美国风险投资巨头红杉资本上个月宣布，将把其中国子公司分拆为一家名为红杉的独立公司，作为全球重组的一部分，该重组还创建了一个独立的公司该品牌专注于印度和东南亚的业务。

;

;Tan 表示，对于 BRV 中国来说，地缘政治风险“不是什么问题”，因为该公司一直与美国兄弟公司分开运营，尽管它们在相同的品牌名称。

;

;谭补充说，BRV 中国的决策是独立做出的，不分享利润和后台服务。

;

;尽管如此，中国在美国的投资仍受到严格审查风险投资行业正在不断发展。

;

;包括纪源资本、金沙江创投、华登国际和高通创投在内的几家美国风险投资公司正因对芯片、人工智能和量子计算的资助而受到美国国会委员会的调查据《华尔街日报》周三报道，中国的公司。

;这是关于 2023 年上半年动荡的经济陷阱和逆风的第二篇文章当张成英第一次告诉她的父母她和她的丈夫不会生孩子时，当他们问张成英时，他们的反应是震惊她是否有什么问题。

;

;没什么，这位 32 岁的女士解释道。他们只想成为一对丁克夫妇——双份收入，没有孩子。他们目前距离这个目标还差两倍的收入，但预计这种情况很快就会改变——他们正在享受开放的道路上的休息时间。

;

;“我母亲说她已经 60 多岁了，会被嘲笑的因为没有孙子，”张说。 “但我会改变自己的生活，只是为了避免她被别人嘲笑吗？没有。”

;

;张刚从山东省一所医科大学毕业，获得药学博士学位，她正在等待时机，等待今年晚些时候在一家医院空缺的科研职位。她的丈夫将在两周后开始在公共机构工作。目前，他们喜欢熬夜、睡懒觉，不用担心孩子。

;

;周四，这对夫妇出发了 5,499 公里（3,417 英里）的公路旅行 - 精心计划了 59 个小时三分钟——这将带他们穿越中国其他三个省份。

;

;“如果我有一个孩子，我绝对不可能这么无忧无虑，”张说。 “由于父母的责任，我的一些朋友很少有时间出去和我见面。”

;

;尽管北京在12月结束了近三年的限制性零新冠措施，它们对人们的经济和精神福祉产生了持久的影响。对于许多人来说，由此产​​生的经济压力和焦虑使他们对未来的前景感到担忧，并且更倾向于拒绝为人父母的想法。

;

;这种趋势在零之前的几年中逐渐兴起。 -新冠疫情期间，全国范围内的停工、停工和广泛的经济不确定性似乎加剧了疫情期间的流动性。

;

;中国的出生率去年创下历史新低，死亡人数首次超过出生人数六十多年来。

;

;“我们认为自己变得更加有自我意识，而我们的父母认为我们变得更加自私，”26 岁的深圳个体户杨晓彤说。< /p>;

;和张一样，杨也不愿意为了孩子而放弃自己的生命和自由。她和她的丈夫于四月结婚，他们说三年的流行病控制对他们的想法产生了很大的影响。除了厌恶生孩子之外，他们开始反思生命的真正意义。

;

;“[我意识到]我想看看整个世界，而不是被孩子限制在一个世界里。”深圳 80 平方米的公寓，”杨说，他的旅行野心与张和其他许多人的愿望一样。 “现在很多年轻人更加注重提高自己的生活质量，因为我们珍惜在这个星球上拥有的时间。”

;

;杨说，自己创业的压力已经够大了。虽然她确实有一些有孩子的朋友，但她也有几个也满足于做丁克人，还有一些甚至不想结婚。

;

;任远，人口研究所教授复旦大学教授表示，这种情绪将对国家产生长期影响。

;

;“考虑到结婚率下降和未婚人口比例上升，中国将非常未来几十年，中国的低生育率可能仍将保持在较低水平。

;

;根据国家统计局的数据，2022年总人口比2021年减少85万人，这是61年来人口首次下降。年。首胎生育率也下降至0.5。

;

;“有研究发现，生育的经历本身就可以提升人们的生育意愿，所以现在中国最大的担忧就是生育率过低。”南开大学人口与发展研究所教授陈为民表示，“一胎家庭的生育率越来越高。”

;

;与此同时，生育成本的上升，加上当前的生育成本上升，经济低迷，超过五分之一的年轻人失业——意味着更多的夫妇发现自己无力抚养孩子。

;

;“说实话，扣除房租、水电费和生活费后，没有多少钱可以养活孩子。”我每月 5000 元（700 美元）的工资还剩下钱，”山东省 24 岁的护士屈云说。她说，她不想要孩子的主要原因是缺钱和时间——她每天工作超过12个小时，连午饭时间都没有，更不用说要孩子了。

;

;尽管如此越来越多的地方政府和企业正在推行补贴作为生育激励措施，瞿先生的想法仍然没有被吓倒。

;

;“政府最好加强对劳工权利的保护，比如规范加班和加班等。” “提高工资，而不是试图说服人们结婚生子。”曲说。

;

;即使是拥有高级教育证书、可以找到相对较高薪工作的张，仍然担心能够充分供养孩子。她会关注亲戚们的支出，尤其是在辅导上的支出，以便让他们的孩子在如此有争议的经济中占据一席之地。

;

;“教育成本如此之高，我不希望我的孩子出生在这样的环境中。”张说。

;

;随着人口危机的迫近，中国减少了农民工结婚的繁文缛节

;

;与此同时，心理健康问题正在上升，包括年轻人的心理健康问题。在大流行的孤立主义时代，让孩子融入其中的想法似乎令人畏惧。

;

;同时应对抑郁症，当孩子变得淘气时，“让我们更难保持耐心”，杨南开大学陈教授表示，即使是与成年人的人际关系也变得更加难以处理。在社交媒体上，不可否认的是，中国必须让社会变得更有利于生育婴幼儿，以“建立儿童友好型社会”为目标。

;

;China issued a comprehensive action plan on Wednesday to support its private businesses amid a weakening economic recovery.

;

;Despite the end of Beijing's strict zero-Covid policy, business confidence has remained low and many firms are on the edge of closure.

;

;Having served as the backbone for the economy as the biggest contributor to employment and innovation, the private sector has been a topic of heated debate over the past decade.

;

;It has also previously received multiple rounds of policy support.

;

;

;

;The new plan, which includes 31 measures, for the first time called private companies “fresh troops in pushing forward China's modernisation”, emphasising their strategic importance in China's future growth.

;

;Vowing to make them “bigger, better and stronger”, the plan rolled out a series of measures that responded directly to the major concerns shared by business owners, including difficulty in obtaining payments from governments and state-owned companies (SOEs).

;

;China's economic backbone, private firms decry lack of parity in policy support

;

;The most comprehensive policy package issued since President Xi Jinping started his third presidential term in March, the plan also called for a more tolerant environment for private firms and more social respect for entrepreneurship and innovation.

;

;There should be an atmosphere of “encouraging innovation and tolerating failure”, it said.

;

;

;

;While business leaders, including Tencent's Pony Ma and Xiaomi's Lei Jun, welcomed the plan, others expressed concern whether all the measures could be implemented.

;

;In an article published by state television on Wednesday, Ma said the measures were clear and “highly targeted”, and that they “have stabilised expectations for realising high-quality development”.

;

;But smaller industry players are worried the plan is just paying lip service, as despite plenty of government pledges to boost the private economy over the years, issues such as unfair competition from SOEs, less access to funding, excessive government supervision and a lack of legal protection, have continued to trouble private companies.

;

;Aside from impact from the coronavirus pandemic, many private firms, including platform companies, property developers and private tutoring services, have also suffered from Beijing's regulatory crackdown.

;

;

;

;While promising tolerance and urging social understanding for the private sector, Beijing has been tightening its grip on businesses, with phrases related to the Communist Party appearing 11 times in the plan.

;

;It vowed to “actively and prudently” develop party members among private companies, strengthen education about socialist values and “explore new ways” to build the party.

;

;As growth falters, China's private sector struggles, and jobs take a hit

;

;Having emerged as a global power, largely due to the freeing up of private businesses over four decades ago, China allowed entrepreneurs to become party members in 2001 to recognise their stronger role.

;

;And any private company with more than three party members is obliged to set up a party cell, according to the Communist Party Charter.

;

;

;

;It has been argued that China's SOEs are advancing, while the private sector has been retreating since the 2000s.

;

;Private firms' anxiety about their fate reached a peak in 2018 when a viral post online urged them to “leave the stage” as their “task of assisting the state-owned economy in achieving its rapid development” had been fulfilled.

;

;Despite denials from the authorities in the following years, private companies are yet to enjoy a level playing field, encounter stricter market entry and are regarded as being riskier when trying to obtain bank loans.

;

;Chinese authorities approve new guidelines for private firms

;

;In the post-Covid climate, state giants are faring better than their private counterparts. In the first half of the year, fixed-asset investment by private firms fell 0.2 per cent from the previous year, in sharp contrast with the rise of 8.1 per cent among their state-owned rivals.

;

;Profits for private industrial enterprises with an annual revenue of at least 20 million yuan (US$2.8 million) fell by 21.3 per cent in the first five months of the year, compared with a drop of 17.7 per cent by SOEs.

;

;

;

;US lawmakers' debate over how best to handle the US-China economic relationship was on full view at a congressional hearing on Thursday, with many Republicans arguing for a complete decoupling while some Democrats contended such a move would weaken American companies.

;

;Representative Blaine Luetkemeyer, a Missouri Republican, took aim at Thea Rozman Kendler, assistant secretary of commerce for export administration, during her testimony before the House select committee on China.

;

;Luetkemeyer suggested that approvals for exports to Chinese companies including Huawei Technologies, along with the long-running US trade deficit with China, helped Beijing “build detention camps against their own people, subsidise their industries against ours and build up their military”.

;

;“We've got to stop everything going to China,” Luetkemeyer said. “If we don't, they use everything against us, and your willingness to continue to play games with them and be a partner with them endangers us down the road.

;

;“When they overtake us [economically], we're done,” he added, citing a Goldman Sachs estimate that China “will finally be able to overtake the United States within the next 10 years”.

;

;“They will be able to dictate all sorts of things to all their economic partners around the world.”

;

;Kendler contended that the Commerce Department had taken “a litany of steps … to make sure that the Chinese government” did not gain “technology that they can use to threaten US national security interests”. She cited the restrictions on the export of “dual-use civilian technologies by the military”.

;

;The rhetorical battle over US trade and investment with China underscored a growing divide on Washington's approach to Beijing, one of the few fronts on which the two parties have increasingly converged in recent years.

;

;Republicans have seized on a recent resumption of dialogue between high-ranking officials in US President Joe Biden's administration – including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen – and their counterparts in Beijing, characterising these efforts as appeasement.

;

;US-China economic rivalry not 'winner-take-all', Yellen says

;

;As Kendler did on Thursday, the Biden administration often touts restrictions it placed last year on exports of the most advanced semiconductors and their production equipment to China. But Republicans have cited statistics showing high rates of approval for US exporters seeking permits to sell such items to the country.

;

;Earlier this year, Under Secretary of Commerce for Industry and Security Alan Estevez told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that the department and other government agencies approved about 70 per cent of export licence applications involving China in 2022.

;

;Representative Jake Auchincloss, a Massachusetts Democrat, sketched the administration's position on trade and investment with China by leading Kendler through a series of questions, all of which she answered positively.

;

;Could trade with China “give America incorporated scale economies, especially for high fixed costs, low marginal cost industries like biopharmaceuticals or semiconductors or telecoms, so that we can invest more in R&D here”?

;

;Could such trade allow the US industry “have standard-setting and other soft-power prerogatives”?

;

;Might it help “prevent Chinese dominance of large internal markets in a way that would give them that standard setting and soft power”?

;

;Yet not all Democrats completely disagreed with the hawkish assessments by Luetkemeyer and other Republicans that trade with China undermines American interests.

;

;Representative Ro Khanna of California, whose Bay Area district includes Silicon Valley, called the offshoring of manufacturing to China and the resulting growth in US bilateral trade deficits “a bipartisan mistake for 40 years”.

;

;However, Khanna said, addressing the problem should start with efforts to bring steel, aluminium and other “critical industries” back to the US.

;

;“We said we're going to do all the invention and we'll do all this stuff in Silicon Valley,” he said. “You go to places like Lordstown, Ohio, and they're hollowed out.

;

;“If I was there, I'd be terribly upset at failed American leadership for 40 years while we just watched as steel left, as aluminium left.”

;

;American chip companies need access to China: semiconductor trade group

;

;The hearing Thursday was the committee's third public event in a week that included economic disengagement from China as a focal point.

;

;On Wednesday, it hosted a debate with four experts on whether the US should revoke China's permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) status.

;

;PNTR, a US legal designation for most-favoured nation status, was granted to China by then-president Bill Clinton in 2000, letting the two sides align their bilateral trade relationship with the rules of the World Trade Organization, which China acceded to the following year.

;

;While Republicans argued for ending PNTR to eliminate incentives for companies to source from China, Democrats contended that revoking the status would raise taxes on American consumers and lead to retaliatory measures from China without bringing manufacturing jobs back.

;

;In light of the debate, committee members appeared to be considering relatively moderate changes to the status quo.

;

;5 things to know about a possible new US ban on investment in China

;

;One “middle path”, as Auchincloss called it, included reauthorising the generalised system of preferences, a trade programme that provides duty-free treatment for certain US imports from developing countries. Auchincloss said it could help reduce the US trade deficit with China.

;Wildlife authorities have killed the leader of a pack of dingoes that mauled a jogger on a popular Australian tourist island in a ferocious attack that a rescuer said could have been fatal.

;

;Sarah Peet, 23, was attacked by three or four Australian native dogs on Monday as she jogged along a beach at Queensland state's K'gari, the world's largest sand island formerly known as Fraser Island.

;

;The Brisbane resident was flown by helicopter to a mainland hospital in a stable condition. The health department refused to provide an update on her condition on Thursday, citing patient confidentiality.

;

;Wildlife rangers captured and humanely euthanised the leader of the pack on Wednesday, the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service said.

;

;“Euthanising a high-risk dingo is always a last resort and the tough decision by the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service was supported by the island's traditional owners, the Butchulla people,” a service statement said.

;

;The dingo was the second on the island in recent weeks to be killed for biting and threatening behaviour. Authorities blame dingoes' increasing fearlessness on tourists who ignore rules by feeding them or encouraging them to approach to post social media images.

;

;Wary young dingoes avoided humans when pandemic travel restrictions were first eased in late 2021. But their dangerous human interactions are increasing with tourists' encouragement as visitor numbers rise.

;

;She was sunbathing on a beach in Australia. Then a wild dingo appeared

;

;Peet did not deliberately encourage dingoes to approach her. But visitors to the World Heritage-listed Great Sandy National Park are warned against running or jogging outside fenced areas because of the risk that dingoes will chase them.

;

;The dingoes forced Peet into the surf, deploying the same hunting strategy that rangers say they use against large prey such as kangaroos and wallabies.

;

;Tourists Shane and Sarah Moffat were driving along the beach in their SUV when they saw Peet being attacked.

;

;“We've seen two dingoes hanging off the side of her”, Shane Moffat told Nine News television. “她举起手朝我走来，大喊‘救命，救命’，”他说。 “I could see fear in her face, that she wasn't in a good way”.

;

;Moffat said he ran to Peet, forcing himself between her and the pack leader. Moffat bloodied his fingers on the dingo's fangs as he punched it.

;

;Moffat said Peet's injuries included a chunk of flesh missing from her right upper-arm and bite marks to her legs. He doubted she would have survived if he had arrived at the scene any later.

;

;Wildlife rangers agreed that Peet would have died without the Moffats' help. “We believe the people who intervened saved her life that day,” principal ranger Danielle Mansfield said.

;

;The pack leader was one of three dingoes on the island fitted with tracking collars because of their high-risk behaviour.

;

;When he was collared in April, he was around two years old and weighed 17 kilos, which was heavy for a dingo and indicated he had been fed by humans, authorities said.

;A South Florida jury awarded US$800,000 in damages to a little girl who received second-degree burns when a hot Chicken McNugget fell on her leg as her mother pulled away from the drive-through of a McDonald's restaurant.

;

;Lawyers for the family of Olivia Caraballo, who was four when she was burned in 2019, were seeking US$15 million in damages. Jurors reached their verdict after deliberating for less than two hours on Wednesday, the South Florida SunSentinel reported.

;

;The jury's verdict form allotted US$400,000 in damages for the past four years, and another US$400,000 for the future from the McDonald's USA and its franchise operator, Upchurch Foods. A separate jury decided in May that the company and franchise owner were liable for the injury, which occurred outside a McDonald's in Tamarac, near Fort Lauderdale.

;

;“I'm actually just happy that they listened to Olivia's voice and the jury was able to decide a fair judgment,” Olivia's mother, Philana Holmes, told reporters outside the courtroom. “我对此很满意。 I honestly had no expectations, so this is more than fair for me.”

;

;She testified on Tuesday that Olivia, now eight, calls the scar on her inner thigh her “nugget” and is fixated on having it removed, the newspaper reported.

;

;Lawyers for McDonald's argued that the child's discomfort ended when the wound healed, which they said took about three weeks. They contended that the girl's mother is the one who has the problem with the scar, and told jurors that US$156,000 should cover damages, both past and future.

;

;“She's still going to McDonald's, she still asks to go to McDonald's, she's still driving through the drive-through with her mom, getting chicken nuggets,” defence lawyer Jennifer Miller said in her closing argument Wednesday. “她并没有因为受伤而感到困扰。 This is all the mom.”

;

;Defence lawyers declined to speak after the verdict.

;

;Chicken nuggets order led police to Facebook video murderer

;

;Holmes testified that she had bought Happy Meals for her son and daughter, who was sitting in the back seat, and was driving away when the nugget fell on the child's leg. She said that the girl screamed in pain, and when she pulled over in a car park, she realised the nugget was lodged between Oliva's thigh and the seat belt.

;

;The mother testified that at no point did McDonald's warn her the food might be unusually hot. The company testified they follow food safety rules, which require McNuggets to be hot enough to avoid salmonella poisoning, and that what happens with the food once it leaves the drive-through window is beyond their control.

;

;While both sides agreed during the trial in May that the nugget caused the burns, the family's lawyers argued the temperature was above 93 degrees Celsius (200 degrees Fahrenheit), while the defence said it was no more than 71 degrees Celsius (160 degrees Fahrenheit).

;

;Photos the mother took of the burn and sound clips of the child's screams were played in court.

;

;The case may stoke memories of the McDonald's coffee lawsuit of the 1990s, which became an urban legend of sorts about seemingly frivolous lawsuits, even though a jury and judge had found it anything but.

;

;A New Mexico jury awarded Stella Liebeck, 81, US$2.7 million in punitive damages after she was scalded in 1992 by hot coffee from McDonald's that spilled onto her lap, burning her legs, groin and buttocks, as she tried to steady the cup with her legs while prying the lid off to add cream outside a drive-through.

;

;She suffered third-degree burns and spent more than a week in hospital.

;

;She had initially asked McDonald's for US$20,000 to cover hospital expenses, but the company went to trial. A judge later reduced the US$2.7 million award to US$480,000, which he said was appropriate for the “wilful, wanton, reckless” and “callous” behaviour by McDonald's.
